utterances: The allegations of secret CIA terrorist prisons in Eastern Europe; developments there.
The Iraq election last month; what about the results?
And remember a woman in France who got her face transplanted?
And this: a huge story a few months ago.
The grand jury investigation of the White House leak of the name of CIA agent Valerie Plame.
On the ABC News politics' website, The Note, we saw this item.
The grand jury looking into the CIA leak was meeting at 9am eastern time, but what's going on?
And what about the role of Mr. Bush's top political agent, Karl Rove?
So there are questions on this story, and here with answers, NPR White House correspondent, Don Gonyea.
Don, where are we?
Well, let's start by looking ahead.
Lewis Libby.
He's the former chief-of-staff to the Vice President, former top aid to the President, the only person indicted so far in this case.
He'll be in court February third.
There is a court date scheduled.
It's a status conference.
Lawyers will report to the judge.
We could get a trial date at that point.
But it's become the symbol of the city's pension problem, its pension mess.
So, literally, it can't afford it, but beyond that, it comes down to: Do you have the will to try to fix the pension problem or not?
So far, critics of DROP say the answer seems to be no.
Joel Rose, NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
You're listening to MORNING EDITION, from NPR News.
Here are some things to know about an Army staff sergeant who's being honored for exceptional valor on the battlefield.
Robbie Miller was a talented gymnast who loved Shakespeare, and also being a soldier.
He was 24 and on his second tour in Afghanistan with the Green Berets when he was killed in 2008.
It was in remote Kunar Province, and Sergeant Miller was protecting has comrades from a Taliban ambush.
Today at the White House, President Obama will present his parents with the nation's highest military award: the Medal of Honor.�
NPR's Tom Bowman tells the story of that day.
The patrol crept along a dirt road on a January night.
They were just a few miles from the Pakistan border, checking out reports of Taliban activity.
On their left was a sheer cliff.
On their right, the road dropped off sharply to a fast-moving river.
�Our team had actually been in a firefight a couple of times in that area.
Staff Sergeant Nick McGarry was on the patrol.
Staff Sgt.
MCGARRY: So, you know, we called it Ambush Alley.
It quickly lived up to its name.
There was a small skirmish, the Americans quickly beat it back, then the soldiers�crossed the river.
Out front was Staff Sergeant Miller, whose knowledge of the Pashtu language made him a natural to lead the 15 Afghan soldiers working with the Americans.
They moved quietly along a heavily wooded trail, says Major Robert Cusick, when a shout pierced the silence.
An insurgent yelled, Allah Akbar and initiated the ambush, and from that point it was pretty much chaos.
Through their night vision goggles, the Green Berets could see a handful, then dozens of insurgents hiding in the hills.
Major Cusick says the Taliban opened fire with machine guns, rocket-propelled grenades.
Dirt, rocks, lots of dust kicking up around us.
I described it to some of my buddies as standing in the middle of a Roman candle during the Fourth of July.
I mean, it was loud, a lot of explosions and a lot of snaps -you know, the sound you hear when a bullet passes by you.
Staff Sergeant Miller took the brunt of it.
Miller fired his light machine gun, taking out Taliban positions.
That led to a brief lull in the fighting.
Then, says Sergeant McGarry, things got worse.�
Staff Sgt.
MCGARRY: The Afghan soldiers just immediately kind of fled that vicinity because there were so many insurgents to cover.
The Afghan soldiers were supposed to fight with Miller.
Now he was alone.
It's what he did next that saved his fellow soldiers.
Miller held his ground and radioed the other Green Berets.
Bound back, he said, meaning move back to safety.�The muzzle flash from Miller's machine gun was a perfect target for the Taliban.
Staff Sgt.
MCGARRY: The amount of firepower that he was putting out, they were able to focus on him.
Sergeant McGarry says Miller kept firing.
Staff Sgt.
MCGARRY: He pretty much locked down the entire south side of the kill zone.
You know, he was throwing grenades and engaging the enemy -basically, what we say is he was taking the fight to the enemy.
That allowed the Green Berets to move back to care for the wounded -three Afghan soldiers and two Americans, including Major Cusick.
A bullet had pierced his shoulder.�For a time, Cusick and the others could still hear Miller firing to cover their retreat, that distinctive rapid fire of his machine gun.
Had he not done�that, I think possibly I wouldn't be here to talk about it, and there'd be some other guys - to include Afghans - who either lost their lives or sustained pretty significant injuries.
Miller had finally run out of ammunition.
A Taliban bullet killed him.
His body was recovered.
He was laid to rest in a small cemetery in Florida.�
Robbie has a headstone down where he was buried, and the center of that headstone doesn't have anything in the center of it, and it's kind of a groove for an award.
A groove, a space for an award.
Cusick says they all knew Miller would get an award for his courage.
They just didn't know it would be the Medal of Honor.
Tom Bowman, NPR News, Washington.
This is NPR News.
In a standoff with North Korea, the United States and South Korea appear to be talking tough, but treading softly.
The U.S.
and South Korea have postponed naval maneuvers that were expected this week as a show of force against the North.
South Korean and U.S.
officials both concede there are very few options they can use against a dangerously unpredictable North Korean regime.
NPR's Mike Shuster reports from Seoul.
There has been a lot of talk in South Korea about tough sanctions against North Korea.
After all, South Korea is convinced a North Korean submarine mounted a sneak attack torpedoing the South Korean ship the Cheonan in the middle of the night, leaving 46 South Korean sailors dead.
The South Korean government confirmed that belief when an international committee of inquiry concluded a North Korean submarine was responsible.
South Korean President Lee Myung-bak has been talking tough throughout this crisis.
That's the tone he struck a few days ago, speaking through an interpreter at an Asian security conference in Singapore.
(Through translator) North Korea has repeatedly attacked us time and time again, but every time we exercise patience and restraint for the sake of peace and stability of the Korean peninsula.

But if we are to once again tolerate North Korea's blatant act of violence, then I believe that will not promote, but endanger the peace and stability of the Korean peninsula and that of northeast Asia.
Hi.
Thanks so much for having me.

A capital city usually means globetrotters, diplomats, foreign journalists, corporate executives, all speeding from one first-class airport lounge to the next, but as Dan Charles reports, in the capital city of Honduras, Tegucigalpa, the jet set has lost its jets.
Tegucigalpa's airport, called Toncontin, is awfully quiet these days.
Right outside the front door, beat-up old Toyotas are squatting in the special parking lot once reserved for diplomats.
The life went out of this place on the 30th of May.
It was a rainy morning, and one Airbus jet overshot the runway.
It crashed through barriers at the edge of the airport and landed on a nearby road, crushing three cars.
Norman Garcia, Honduras' former ambassador to the United States, survived without a scratch.
He climbed out of an emergency exit and onto the plane's wing.
I walked, you know, along the wing, and said it's too high here.
So I walked all the way to the tip because, you know, the jump was about a couple feet, and so I jumped.
I walked a couple more meters to the sidewalk.
I turn around and said hey, what a (unintelligible).
He's still amazed that only five people died: three in the plane, including the pilot, and two in the cars.
What followed was almost as shocking.
The president of Honduras, Manual Zelaya, banned big jets from Toncontin.
He said it was too dangerous, the runway too short and the mountains around Tegucigalpa too close.
The decision left the city's cosmopolitan classes feeling stranded.
Now when World Bank officials or international aid workers want to leave the country, they have to find their way to Honduras' second city, San Pedro Sula.
That means cramming themselves into little commuter planes or going by car, a four-hour, nerve-shattering dash down a winding two-lane road jammed with trucks and old school busses.
Norman Garcia.
It is amusing.
It is funny.
I mean, do we have to go San Pedro, all the way to San Pedro?
You've got to be kidding.
The Honduran president has proposed another answer.
In a few months, he says, international flights can start landing at a military airport only 40 miles from Tegucigalpa, but Norman Garcia and many others don't believe it's going to happen.
And anyway, because of the bad roads, it still takes two hours to get to that airport.
Believe me, it is very complicated.
We're going nuts in Tegucigalpa.
So Garcia, even though he almost died at Toncontin airport, wants to get back on that short runway.
Let me put it this way.
Toncontin is an old friend.
I have landed in Toncontin more than 600 times, I guess.
I mean, the first time I landed in Toncontin must have been in 1953.
